site.title: One Breath Partnership
site.description: One Breath Partnership elevates the work for clean air for everyone in Houston, Harris County and Texas.
site.home_header: Living every day like an ozone action day.

mainImage.alt: PM 2.5 contributed to 5,000 deaths in Houston alone in 2015. Photo: U.S. Air Force.
mainImage.caption: PM 2.5 contributed to 5,000 deaths in Houston alone in 2015. Photo: U.S. Air Force.

node.title: 'Protective of everyone': A conversation about particle pollution with Rachel Fullmer

children.text: to adopt a stronger federal standard for particle pollution that could have saved as many as 10,000 Americans lives every year?

node.Action1Title: Tell TCEQ that Houston needs more air monitors for PM 2.5

mainImage.alt: Nearly all of Houston lives with levels of particle pollution above 10 micrograms per cubic meter — and many areas are above the current federal standard of 12.
mainImage.caption: Nearly all of Houston lives with levels of particle pollution above 10 micrograms per cubic meter — and many areas are above the current federal standard of 12.

node.title: What is particulate matter?

children.text: "The latest science shows we need stronger, more protective limits," said Rachel Fullmer, senior attorney with the Environmental Defense Fund.

node.Action1Title: Sign our petition to demand TCEQ take its mission seriously

mainImage.caption: Catherine Fraser is a Clean Air Associate with Environment Texas. Photo: Alese Pickering.

node.title: 'It is our future': A conversation with Catherine Fraser

children.text: In 2018, Houston breathed 110 days of unhealthy air. Environment Texas' Clean Air Associate says, 'We still have a long way to go.'

mainImage.alt: IMPACT Fifth Ward led a march on Valentine's Day in February 2020 to remember loved ones lost to cancer. Photo: Matthew Tresaugue.
mainImage.caption: IMPACT Fifth Ward led a march on Valentine's Day in February 2020 to remember loved ones lost to cancer. Photo: Matthew Tresaugue.

node.title: 'We're not going anywhere'

children.text: Living with what experts call 'cumulative impacts' and 'chronic exposures' to pollution, residents in the Fifth Ward are staying unified to serve the cause of environmental justice.

node.Action1Title: Learn more about the environmental burdens communities of color have borne

node.title: 'You can learn faith': A conversation about climate action with Heather McTeer Toney

children.text: The National Field Director of Moms Clean Air Force is "mom-partisan," welcoming anyone concerned about the impacts of climate change and air pollution on our children.

node.Action1Title: Get involved with Moms Clean Air Force in Texas

mainImage.alt: A longtime Environmental Protection Agency toxicologist calls Michael Honeycutt's weakening of TCEQ's standard on ethylene oxide "completely unreasonable."
mainImage.caption: A longtime Environmental Protection Agency toxicologist calls Michael Honeycutt's weakening of TCEQ's standard on ethylene oxide "completely unreasonable."

node.title: How TCEQ made a cancer-causing chemical seem safer than it is

children.text: A devastating investigation by The Intercept shows a "collaboration" between industry and Texas' environmental agency that led to weakened standards on ethylene oxide.

node.Action1Title: Add your name to our petition to #CleanUpTCEQ

mainImage.alt: Most Houstonians believe a lot more should be done to control air pollution, the 2020 Kinder Houston Area Survey shows.
mainImage.caption: Most Houstonians believe a lot more should be done to control air pollution, the 2020 Kinder Houston Area Survey shows.

node.title: In Houston, the new normal should include more efforts to reduce air pollution

children.text: Stay-at-home orders to slow the spread of COVID-19 resulted in Houstonians driving a lot less. But Houston hasn’t stopped being an industrial city during the pandemic, which shows why reducing all air pollution is key to protecting public health.

node.Action1Title: Download the full report from this year's Kinder Houston Area Survey

mainImage.alt: Despite a 40 percent reduction in traffic, Houston, NPR reports, "did not breathe significantly cleaner air."
mainImage.caption: Despite a 40 percent reduction in traffic, Houston, NPR reports, "did not breathe significantly cleaner air."

node.title: Traffic is down because of stay-home orders, but air pollution? Not so much

children.text: Despite a 40 percent reduction in traffic, NPR reports, "Houston did not breathe significantly cleaner air."

node.title: In the shadows of America's smokestacks, the coronavirus is one more deadly risk

node.Action1Title: See how air pollution hasn't gone away during the pandemic

mainImage.alt: EPA scientists found that strengthening the current standard for fine particulate matter could save more than 10,000 American lives every year. EPA leadership declined to.
mainImage.caption: EPA scientists found that strengthening the current standard for fine particulate matter could save more than 10,000 American lives every year. EPA leadership declined to.

node.title: Air pollution was already killing us. Then came the coronavirus. Where's the EPA?

children.text: By refusing to listen to its own scientists and strengthen a federal air quality standard for fine particulate matter, the EPA is putting more Americans at risk.

node.Action1Title: Leave a public comment about the EPA's decision by June 29, 2020
